## Overview

This manuscript, “Active Inference as a Meta-Pragmatic and Meta-Epistemic Method,” presents a novel framework for understanding cognitive science and cognitive security implications. It proposes a systematic approach to Active Inference, moving beyond traditional free energy minimization to emphasize the crucial role of meta-level specification of epistemic and pragmatic frameworks. The research aims to provide a more robust and adaptable model of cognition, particularly relevant for addressing complex challenges in areas like artificial intelligence and human-machine interaction.

## Key Contributions

The core contribution of this work lies in the introduction of a (2 ×2) matrix framework that structures Active Inference’s theoretical contributions across four distinct quadrants. These quadrants – Data/Meta-Data and Cognitive/Meta-Cognitive – provide a systematic lens for analyzing cognitive processes, enabling researchers to precisely define the frameworks within which agents operate. Specifically, the manuscript details how the Expected Free Energy (EFE) formulation, when viewed through this meta-level framework, becomes a methodology for specifying pragmatic landscapes and controlling cognitive processes. Furthermore, the paper highlights the implications of this approach for cognitive security, identifying vulnerabilities arising from manipulation of belief formation and value structures. The framework’s ability to integrate diverse levels of processing—from basic sensory data to higher-order reasoning—represents a significant advancement in the field.

## Methodology Summary

The manuscript employs a primarily theoretical approach, developing a new framework for analyzing Active Inference. This framework is built around a (2 ×2) matrix representation, dividing cognitive processing into four quadrants based on the axes of Data/Meta-Data and Cognitive/Meta-Cognitive. The methodology involves detailed descriptions of each quadrant, outlining how Active Inference operates at each level. The paper meticulously defines the mathematical formulations associated with each quadrant, including the EFE equation and its components, and provides illustrative examples to demonstrate the framework’s application. The core of the methodology is the systematic specification of epistemic and pragmatic frameworks, allowing for a more controlled and nuanced understanding of cognitive behavior.

## Principal Results

The framework’s conceptual demonstration reveals that Active Inference transcends traditional reinforcement learning by enabling the specification of pragmatic landscapes. The mathematical examples illustrate how the EFE can be manipulated to achieve specific goals and adapt to changing environments. The framework highlights the importance of meta-data integration for enhancing cognitive performance, demonstrating how incorporating information about data processing can improve reliability and accuracy. The analysis reveals that the modeler’s dual role – as both an architect and a subject – is crucial for the framework’s effectiveness.
